data.title: Implement reference streaming
data.body:
This PR implements the necessary changes in vscode to support streaming the response for "Find all references" requests as described in #20010 (please read this issue for complete context).

Streaming results makes reference requests more responsive for large repos since the user does not have to wait for all results to start seeing some results. If the user interacts with the reference results before they have finished streaming in, their position and state will be preserved.

Before merging:
- [ ] Use ProgressCallback
- [ ] Fix CI errors
    ```
    src/vs/editor/contrib/referenceSearch/browser/referencesModel.ts:32:32:Unexternalized string found: ":"
    src/vs/editor/contrib/referenceSearch/browser/referencesModel.ts:36:96:Unexternalized string found: ":"
    /home/travis/build/Microsoft/vscode/src/vs/workbench/test/node/api/extHostLanguageFeatures.test.ts(592,11): Supplied parameters do not match any signature of call target.
    ```

data.title: Can't debug unit tests on fresh checkout
data.body:
Environment
- macOS Sierra 10.12.2
- node 6.9.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Checkout Microsoft/vscode (Tried at 6fccb17169d1a757f13addef46b4eb4132ef9692 and 62383be39eefb80cf70786d616339dd68632afee)
2. ./scripts/npm.sh install
3. npm run watch
4. Open VS Code (I have tried 1.9.1 and insider build on 2017-02-14) in the directory
5. Set a breakpoint in ExtHostLanguageFeatures.test.ts inside test `References, registration order`
6. Run the Unit Tests launch configuration
7. It appears to run some unit tests and then stops with this message
```
[0209/102815:ERROR:tcp_listen_socket.cc(76)] Could not bind socket to 127.0.0.1:23457
[0209/102815:ERROR:node_debugger.cc(86)] Cannot start debugger server
```

I also tried running the command "Tasks: Run Test Task" which failed with this message
```
[10:54:50] Using gulpfile ~/code/vscode/gulpfile.js
[10:54:50] Starting 'test'...
{ errorCode: 'load',
  moduleId: 'gc-signals',
  neededBy: [ 'vs/workbench/api/node/mainThreadHeapService' ],
  detail: 
   Error: Module version mismatch. Expected 48, got 50.
       at Error (native)
       at Object.Module._extensions..node (module.js:597:18)
       at Module.load (module.js:487:32)
       at tryModuleLoad (module.js:446:12)
       at Function.Module._load (module.js:438:3)
       at Module.require (module.js:497:17)
       at require (internal/module.js:20:19)
       at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/nick/code/vscode/node_modules/gc-signals/src/index.js:8:18)
       at Module._compile (module.js:570:32)
       at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:579:10)
       at Module.load (module.js:487:32)
       at tryModuleLoad (module.js:446:12)
       at Function.Module._load (module.js:438:3)
       at Module.require (module.js:497:17)
       at require (internal/module.js:20:19)
       at NodeScriptLoader.load (/Users/nick/code/vscode/out/vs/loader.js:609:39) }
```

data.title: Create multiple folders at once in explorer
data.body:
QOL things that make VSCode more convenient and closer to being basically a replacement for most IDEs for me. The editor gives you some control over what you can do within the project folder using the view panel on the left, e.g. new file, new folder. Languages like Java, its derivatives, and a lot of others organize code through a series of folders containing nothing but yet another folder, eventually leading to actual content. It would be convenient if the editor let one create multiple at once in one action, with each folder separated by a slash character (/, \\, \\\\) like in path definitions.

![Example input](http://i.imgur.com/Ak1L5mA.png)

To add onto this functionality, the view bar can be excessively wide just to display subfolders with their correct indentation. Folders containing nothing but a single other folder can be displayed in short-hand to instead display a path leading to the next folder containing more than one directory.

```
src/main
|-- java
    |-- me/scarlet/dbot
        |-- DiscordBot.java
|-- scala
    |-- me/scarlet/dbot
        |-- DiscordBot.scala
```

Steps to Reproduce:

In Windows, you get tiny icons to the left of every language, however this is not the case for Ubuntu.

![Ubuntu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6411451/22796625/ea0af516-eeaf-11e6-8296-d57ac0b3a710.png)

Not sure if this is a bug, but just pointing it out.

data.title: Enhancement: auto-closing brackets to include backticks?
data.body: In working with ES6(+),  I find myself using backticks quite a lot, generally for string template literals (i.e., `` `item count is ${items.length}` ``)  I'd like to have Code auto-close backticks in javascript, like it currently does with brackets and single/double quotes.  BTW, this is the default behavior in Atom.

data.title: Markdown live preview doesn't update with missing file extension
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1 Win
- OS Version: Windows 10 & OSX

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create and open markdown file without `.md` extension
2. Open preview editor to the side
3. Make changes to the file
4. Live update doesn't work, neither does reopening the preview
5. Rename the file to have the `.md` extension
6. Live preview still doesn't work
7. Close and reopen file and preview
8. Live preview now works

data.title: macOS: set acceptFirstMouse for windows
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VSCode, open a new document and have an active terminal visible.
2. Verify the cursor can actively type in terminal, switch focus to document... type some text.  Verify cursor is still in the document.
3. Switch focus to another program via mouse click.
4. Switch focus back to VSCode via mouse click within the terminal window area.  Note that the focus in the active document is maintained and focus does not switch to the terminal.
5. A second click in the terminal area switches focus to the terminal.

Expected Behavior:

When clicking in the terminal window (or the editor) to switch focus to VSCode the focus is expected to be in the area of the program clicked.  Focus should not be retained in the previously active area it should switch to the selected component.  The is especially frustrating when multiple editor panes are displayed along with a terminal.  Essentially a 'double click to focus' is required at all times to ensure focus is actually in the portion of the program expected.

data.title: When vscode is out of date, some extensions keep showing "update" button even after updating
data.body:
- VSCode Version: previous versions
- OS Version: all

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Update an extension whose latest release requires a newer version of code than what you have installed. (e.g code < 1.8.0 and cmake tools < v7.2)
2. The green "update" button will remain even after performing an update (of the extension only), but the extension version doesn't increment

This behavior actually kind of makes sense, but the problem is it since the user at this point is just trying to update extensions, it makes it seem like the updater is broken. There's no feedback loop that says "hey, you can't update to the latest version of the extension _because_ your vscode version is too old". 

OR, maybe vscode shouldn't show extensions as update-able if they can't be updated with your current version of code. It would be more intuitive certainly.

data.title: Background color is blocky when displayed on an external monitor on macOS
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3 on MacBook Pro Retina 15-inch Mid 2014

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Connect an external monitor to the Macbook (HDMI or DisplayPort)
2. Open VSCode
3. Drag VSCode to the external monitor

See the attached screenshot showing the problem. It's worth noting that the problem doesn't happen if I disable GPU acceleration with the --disable-gpu flag.

![vscode-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3686835/22793638/a5886a42-eead-11e6-992c-fe080d63a180.png)

data.title: GitHub sync fails when two-factor authentication is enabled

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04, 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make changes to a GitHub repo with two-factor authentication enabled
2. Push/Sync changes.

> Error: Authentication failed on the git remote.

A dialog box appears to enter your git username/password, but there is no subsequent dialog for the two-factor authentication code, and so the process just fails. 

The `https` protocol was used for the `git clone` on this repo.

data.title: VS CODE Team,
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-09T00:26:45.394Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.6.2|
|mono-debug|ms-vscode|0.13.0|

---

I had spent 2-3 hours last night creating a THEME, in place under...

C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions

...I was enjoying using my new theme this morning when VS CODE announced a update was available.

After the update was install, *blam* all my work last night is gone, my Theme and all assocaited files *gone*, not in the trash, no where to be found.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a Theme in C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions
2. Allow an auto-update of VS-CODE to take place
3. Try to use your custom theme... GONE.

data.title: Deleting braces/quotes after auto closing doesn't delete both, deletes only opening one.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3 and Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type {, (, [, ', ". Depending on what is typed VSCode will close it. like {|}, (|), [|], "|", '|'. (The pipe represents the cursor).
2. Press Delete. Only the opening one get deleted, the closing one at end does not get deleted. After pressing delete it is like |}, |], |), |", |'.
3. I expect a setting to set that will allow deleting both on one delete. Some may prefer what it is currently doing. So that's why requesting a setting.
4. I also expect it to delete both when I put the cursor in two of these and press delete any time, even after coming back to the file after a day or two. 

Undoing is another option, I know, but still, suppose I put the cursor somewhere else and came back or modifying existing code, this setting will increase my productivity.

I am raising this issue because this functionality exists in Sublime Text 3 and I love it!

data.title: Opening from command-line in empty folder creates debug.log file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. `mkdir test && cd test`
2. `code .`
3. See the `debug.log` file:

```
[0209/110457:ERROR:tcp_listen_socket.cc(76)] Could not bind socket to 127.0.0.1:6004
[0209/110457:ERROR:node_debugger.cc(86)] Cannot start debugger server
```

4. Now delete the `debug.log` file
5. The file is immediately created again (you have to refresh the explorer pane to see it, but you can see it in Windows Explorer or command line immediately)

This does not happen if you have a window open and open the folder through the UI
